themes.label: Decrees
themes.rationale: The text is a formal decree issued by the city of Kotyrta, as indicated by the standard formula 'it seemed good to the city'.
themes.quote: δοξε τ ι πλει τ ν κοτυρτατ ν

themes.label: Honorific Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The inscription honors an individual by granting him the titles of proxenos and euergetes (benefactor) of the city.
themes.quote: πρ]ξενον μεν κα ε εργ τ[αν] τ ς π λιος

themes.label: Accounts and Financial Records
themes.rationale: The decree records a financial transaction where the honored individual provided an interest-free loan of money to the city.
themes.quote: δανε[ σαι τ ι] π λει ργ ριον

themes.label: Agonistic / Victory Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The decree mentions the privilege of proedria (front-row seating) at gymnastic games as part of the honors granted.
themes.quote: ε ς προεδρ αν ν το ς [γυ]μνικο ς γ σιν

themes.label: Stele
themes.rationale: The text explicitly orders the decree to be inscribed on a stone stele.
themes.quote: ε ς στ λαν λιθ ναν

themes.label: Other Stone
themes.rationale: The inscription describes the material as stone (lithinan) without specifying a particular type like marble or limestone.

themes.label: Fragmentary
themes.rationale: The text contains numerous lacunae and restored sections, indicating it is a fragmentary inscription.

themes.label: Damaged but Legible
themes.rationale: Despite the missing letters and surface damage, the core content and legal formulas of the decree remain legible.

rationale: This inscription is a proxeny decree from the Laconian city of Kotyrta. It honors a man named Kratesis son of Kousopas for his significant financial contribution to the city in the form of an interest-free loan. In recognition of his and his ancestors' services, the city grants him the titles of proxenos and euergetes. These honors include hereditary privileges such as asylia (inviolability), isopoliteia (equal citizenship rights), ateleia (tax exemption), and proedria (priority seating) at athletic games. The decree was to be inscribed on a stone stele and dedicated in the sanctuary of Apollo Hyperteleatas to ensure public visibility of the city's gratitude. The mention of the ephors 'around Eucratidas' serves as a dating formula.
